title: Amalgam
definition: a mixture or blend
examples: a curious amalgam of the traditional and the modern.
an amalgam of strength, reputation, and commitment to ethical principles.
origin: late 15th century: from French amalgame or medieval Latin amalgama, from Greek malagma ‘an emollient’.

title: Galvanize
definition: shock or excite (someone) into taking action.

cases.text: shock or excite (someone) into taking action.
cases.use: the impassioned speach galvanized the onlookers

cases.text: coat (iron or steel) with a protective layer of zinc.
cases.use: it was a sample of galvanized steel

examples: the urgency of his voice galvanized them into action.
The country was galvanized in the weeks and months after 9/11.
origin: early 19th century (in the sense ‘stimulate by electricity’): from French galvaniser (see Galvani, Luigi).

title: Acrimony
definition: bitterness or ill feeling.

cases.use: the acrimony in his words stung.

examples: the acrimony in his words stung.
Her acrimony for her neighbors manifests itself with shouting and stomping.
origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘bitter taste or smell’): from French acrimonie or Latin acrimonia, from acer, acri- ‘pungent, acrid’.

title: Arduous
definition: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring
examples: the arduous work of preparing a Dictionary of the English Language.
an arduous journey.
origin: mid 16th century: from Latin arduus ‘steep, difficult’+ -ous.

title: Wanting
definition: lacking in a certain required or necessary quality; not existing or supplied; absent
examples: The analysis was wanting in reliable data.
Compassion was wanting in his interactions with others.
origin: mid 16th century: from Latin arduus ‘steep, difficult’+ -ous.

title: Demur
definition: To object or show reluctance; raise doubts or objection or show reluctance
examples: He would have normally demurred to such a proposal, but he accepted.
Jack disliked salads, so he demurred when his wife suggested he try Kale.
origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘linger, delay’): from Old French demourer (verb), demeure (noun), based on Latin de- ‘away, completely’ + morari ‘delay’.

title: Parsimonious
definition: unwilling to spend money or use resources; extremely frugal, miserly
examples: Kate was so parsimonious that she never went out to eat with coworkers, even when her friends would beg her to join.

title: Anomalous
definition: Unusual or unexpected; out of the ordinary
examples: The patient's behaviour was altogether anomalous

title: Equivocal
definition: Open to more than one interpretation; not easy to explain or understand.
examples: The president's response to the question was equivocal.

title: Lucid
definition: Easy to understand; clearly expressed
examples: He could write in a clear and lucid manner.

title: Precipitate
definition: To cause something to happen suddenly or without warning
examples: The heated argument precipitated a physical altercation.

title: Assuage
definition: To make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense; satisfy
examples: The compliments assuaged the king's anger.

title: Erudite
definition: Having or displaying great knowledge or learning
examples: The philosopher's discussion was erudite

title: Opaque
definition: Not able to be seen through; not easily understood
examples: The glass was so scratched that it had become opaque.
The book's meaning was opaque to the reader.

title: Prodigal
definition: Wastefully extravagant; spending resources freely and recklessly.
examples: The prodigal son had finally returned after a summer traveling through europe.
Her prodigal habits had left her without money or a home.

title: Enigma
definition: Something that is mysterious, puzzling, or hard to understand.
examples: The foreigner was an enigma to the young man.
The instructions were enigmatic.

title: Fervid
definition: Intensely passionate or enthusiastic, usually to excess.
examples: The super fan shook the star's hand in a fervid manner.

title: Placate
definition: To make (someone) less angry or hostile.
examples: The son tried to placate his mother with apologies.

title: Zeal
definition: Great enthusiam or passion for a cause or objective.
examples: The developer's zeal for learning landed him a prestigious job.

title: Abstain
definition: To restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something
examples: The patient was told to abstain from eating greasy foods.

title: Audacious
definition: a willingness to take bold surprising risks; showing a lack of respect.
examples: The CEO's audacious business plan made him millions.
The audacious remark landed Jessie in detention.

title: Desiccate
definition: To dry out; to remove the water from something
examples: In the summer heat the plant had become completely desiccated.

title: Laudable
definition: worthy of praise and recognition.
examples: Eliminating world hunger is a laudable goal.

title: Pedant
definition: someone who is overly concerned with minor details and rules or with showing academic learning
examples: Jack, a well-known pedant, would always correct his peers on the pronounciation of words.

title: Vacillate
definition: Be indecisive; to waver between different actions or opinions.
examples: The student would regularly vacillate between going out and staying in to study.

title: Adulterate
definition: To cause something to be impure or weaker by adding something to it;
examples: The drink had been adulterated with water, reducing its potency.

title: Capricious
definition: Prone to sudden changes in mood or behavior.
examples: The capricious judge might lengthen someone's sentence depending on the day.

title: Engender
definition: To bring about, cause, or produce (something)
examples: Hateful words can engender violence.

title: Homogenous
definition: Of the same or similar kind
examples: Culturally speaking, the neighborhood was often described as too homogenous.

title: Loquacious
definition: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
examples: The loquacious professor could spend the entire class time answering a single question.

title: Pragmatic
definition: Dealing with problems in a reasonable and logical way rather than relying on theories.
examples: The teacher used a pragmatic approach to teaching

title: Apathy
definition: Lack of interest, enthusiasm or concern
examples: Apathy was widespread among the younger voting population.

title: Ineffable
definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words
examples: The view from atop the mountain was Ineffable.

title: Exegesis
definition: Critical explanation or interpretation of a text, usually a scripture.
examples: The arduous work of biblical exegesis.

title: Inexorable
definition: Impossible to stop or prevent; impossible to persuade by request.
examples: The inexorable setting of the sun.

title: Pontificate
definition: Express one's opinions in a pompous and dogmatic way.
examples: The philosopher would pontificate about dialectical materialism.

title: Prolific
definition: To create many works; producing many fruits or offspring; present in large numbers or quantities
examples: The prolific artist had works in half the museams in the city.
This species of frog is quite a prolific breeder.
The now extinct bat was once prolific in these areas.

title: Exasperate
definition: Irritate and frustrate someone intensely.
examples: The drama left him feeling exasperated.

title: Auspicious
definition: Conducive to success; favorable
examples: The weather was not the most auspicious for sailing
